summary.text_en: On his deathbed, Copernicus published his foundational work 'On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres'. In it, he presented a mathematically complete 'Heliocentric' model, placing the Sun at the center of the universe and demoting the Earth to just another planet orbiting it.
key_points_en: Earth is treated as a planet
Earth's rotation explains day and night

story.text_en: Copernicus spent decades refining his heliocentric model but hesitated to publish, fearing persecution from the Church and ridicule from academia. Only late in his life, at the strong urging of his friends and pupils (like Rheticus), did he agree. Legend says he received the first printed copy of his book on his deathbed, just hours before he died in May 1543.

fun_facts.text_en: The publisher, Andreas Osiander, added an anonymous preface without Copernicus's permission, claiming the model was merely a 'mathematical hypothesis' for calculation, not physical reality. This likely saved it from immediate censorship by the Church.
Copernicus was not the first to propose heliocentrism. The ancient Greek astronomer Aristarchus of Samos had proposed it in the 3rd century BC, but his idea was not accepted.

simple_explanation.text_en: Before Copernicus, everyone believed Earth was the center of the universe (like thinking you're the center of a party). The Sun, Moon, and all planets orbited Earth. Copernicus said, 'No, we have it backwards.' He showed that the Sun is the center, and Earth is just one of many planets orbiting it. This completely changed how we see our place in the universe.

applications.text_en: The heliocentric model allowed astronomers for the first time to calculate the relative distances of the planets in the Solar System (e.g., that Mars is 1.5x further from the Sun than Earth).

applications.text_en: Copernicus's more accurate calculation for the length of a year provided the key mathematical basis for the Gregorian Calendar reform in 1582 (the calendar we use today).

applications.text_en: It provided the essential theoretical framework for the later work of Kepler, Galileo, and Newton, whose discoveries would not have been possible without it.

impact.text_en: This book is widely seen as the starting point of the Scientific Revolution. It fundamentally challenged the 1,500-year-old Aristotelian and Ptolemaic geocentric model, moving humanity from the center of the universe to the periphery. This shift is known as the 'Copernican Revolution'.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ptolemy's geocentric model (as the primary theory to be disproven)
Aristarchus of Samos (as the ancient originator of heliocentrism)
Ibn al-Shatir (his Maragha school model provided the key mathematical tools to replace the equant)

influenced.contribution_en: Tycho Brahe (his work was a direct response to Copernicus, attempting to create a third model)
Provided the framework and data for Kepler to calculate elliptical orbits
Provided the theoretical model for Galileo to confirm with his telescope

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Copernicus removed Earth from its privileged, central position in the universe, sparking a scientific and intellectual revolution that continues to this day.

quiz.question_en: What was the revolutionary idea proposed by Copernicus in his 1543 book 'De revolutionibus'?
quiz.explanation_en: Copernicus's model (Heliocentrism) challenged the accepted Ptolemaic model (Geocentrism) by proposing that the Earth, like the other planets, orbited the Sun.
